message: The U.S. used to lead the world in the percentage of its people who graduated college. Now, among the younger generation, we are in fifteenth place behind Australia, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Ireland, Israel, Japan, South Korea, Luxembourg, Norway, Sweden and the U.K. We will not be globally competitive without a well-educated population. We need to make public colleges and universities tuition-free.

I was pleased to stand with Governor Andrew Cuomo today as he proposed making public colleges and universities tuition free in New York State. This is an idea I have long supported, and an idea whose time has come. If the United States is to succeed in a highly-competitive global economy, we need the best educated workforce in the world. That means that all Americans, regardless of income, must have the right to a higher education. Donald Trump wants to give huge tax breaks to billionaires.  We want to make public colleges and universities tuition free. We are right. Trump is wrong. Let's fight for tuition free public colleges and universities in every state in the country.

The Republicans’ goal is to take away health insurance from tens of millions of Americans, end Medicare as we know it, make massive cuts to Medicaid, increase prescription drug prices, and defund Planned Parenthood. We cannot let them get away with it. We have got to fight back.

Either Donald Trump simply lied to the elderly and the working people of this country and just made campaign promises that he had no intention of ever keeping. Or Donald Trump has got to come forward and say clearly that Donald Trump will veto any legislation that cuts Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security.

On May 7th, 2015, Donald Trump tweeted: "I was the first & only potential GOP candidate to state there will be no cuts to Social Security, Medicare & Medicaid." Mr. Trump must keep his word and tell Republicans he will veto any legislation that cuts these vital and necessary programs.
Rep. Mick Mulvaney, Trump's choice for budget director, speaks for himself.

I think that it's basically insane for Republicans to try to repeal the Affordable Care Act and throw tens of millions of people off health insurance, raise prescription drug prices and do away with patient protections, without having any alternative in place.

We forget that it was only seven years ago that somebody with breast cancer or another serious illness could be denied by insurance companies. That is insane. What's the function of insurance if you can't get it when you need it? But as a result of the Affordable Care Act, we've said to the insurance companies, "No, you can't discriminate against someone with a pre-existing condition."

Our immigration system is broken. We need comprehensive immigration reform that provides a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants living in the shadows, keeps families together and promotes civil, human and labor rights for all.

Americans pay by far the highest cost for prescription drugs in the world. So tonight, I'm offering an amendment which says something very straightforward: pharmacists and prescription drug distributors should be able to purchase low-cost medicine from other countries at a fraction of the price they're paying in the United States.

I live 50 miles away from Canada, and in many cases they pay 50% less for the same exact medicine that we buy in Vermont and the rest of America. And we all know the reason why: the power and wealth of the pharmaceutical industry. Their 1,300 lobbyists and unlimited sums of money have bought the United States Congress.

How are we going to end the international embarrassment of being the only major country that does not guarantee health care as a right? It definitely isn't by throwing another 30 million people off insurance without a replacement plan.

"America, the richest and most powerful nation in the world, can well lead the way in this revolution of values. There is nothing, except a tragic death wish, to prevent us from reordering our priorities, so that the pursuit of peace will take precedence over the pursuit of war." –Martin Luther King, Jr., April 4, 1967

Let us not forget where Dr. Martin Luther King was when he was assassinated. He was standing up with exploited workers. He was saying that in this country of incredible wealth why do we have so many people living in poverty. To truly honor Dr. King we must fight to carry out his radical and bold vision for America and transform our national priorities.

New estimates from the Congressional Budget Office say that the Republicans' health care plan, which is supported by Trump's nominee for Health and Human Services, would throw 32 million more people off health insurance and double premiums by 2026. That approach takes us in exactly the wrong direction.

Today I asked Rep. Tom Price a simple question: Does he believe that health care is a right of all Americans, whether you are rich or poor? His answer: "We are a compassionate society." That is wrong. In terms of our relationship to poor and working people, we are not a compassionate society. Our record is worse than virtually any major country on earth.

Today is going to be a tough day for millions of Americans, including myself. But we cannot throw up our hands in despair. We have to fight back as effectively and as vigorously as we can. We are not giving up.

Mr. Trump, you are not going to divide us up by gender, by race, by who we love. Your bigotry is bringing us together in a progressive movement. We are not going to retreat on women's rights, immigration rights, workers' rights, health care rights, racial justice or climate change.

But I am very concerned that his nomination of Congressmen Mulvaney to be budget director is the clearest example we have that Trump has no intention of keeping the promises he made.

We need to rebuild our crumbling infrastructure. Despite being the wealthiest nation on earth, most Republicans for years have refused to invest in our roads and bridges, our water systems, our wastewater plants, our airports and rail system. Further, we need quality and affordable broadband throughout rural and urban America and state of the art schools. Instead of providing huge tax breaks to the wealthy and large corporations, we need a one trillion dollar infrastructure investment which will not only make our country safer, more productive and more efficient, it will create up to 15 million good paying jobs. Let's do it.

We must have a qualified and knowledgeable Secretary of Education, not a multi-billionaire who has made hundreds of millions in campaign contributions to right-wing Republicans. Betsy DeVos must not become Secretary of Education.

What President Trump did in his ban on all immigrants from seven majority-Muslim countries is un-American, is unconstitutional and is going to make us less safe, not more safe. This country has always welcomed people into our nation. To tell over a billion Muslims that they are not welcome to come into the United States sends a horrible message and something that runs absolutely contrary to American values.
Taking on Trump will not be easy. We have to be smart about it and we have to stand together.

First, with Trump attacking the media as "fake news," attacking a judge whose decision he didn't like as a "so-called judge," attacking U.S. intelligence agencies as operating in Nazi-like ways and attacking the entire U.S. Congress as unresponsive to the needs of the American people, he was moving this country in an authoritarian direction. The message that Trump is imparting to the American people is that he, and he alone, can be trusted. Make no mistake about it. This is an attack on our democracy and a movement toward authoritarian government.    Secondly, Sanders called Trump a "fraud" and a president who is disavowing virtually every campaign promise that he made to American workers, the elderly, the sick and the poor. Trump campaigned against cuts to Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid - but that's exactly what the Republicans are doing. We're going to tax Wall Street.” Now, of course, he has appointed major Wall Street bankers to his financial team and is giving Wall Street exactly what they want.    Sanders said that the American people are going to resist Trump's movement toward authoritarianism on the streets, in Congress and in the courts. "Too many Americans fought and died to defend American democracy to let President Trump move us in an authoritarian direction.  This is the United States of America.  We are not a Trump business enterprise," Sanders said.    Sanders appeared on CNN's State of the Union program.
